##Why is the US throwing money at helicopters?

Micro Signal China Business Journal

Function introduction, grow in step with Chinese enterprises, talk with business leaders, spread business ideals, serve business people, "China Business News" control of the absolute voice of Chinese business.

![img](data:image/jpeg;base64,)
By Fan Xin

Since March, a series of U.S. stock market meltdowns, so that investors around the world out of a cold sweat, even the Warren Buffett are "see you soon. " The Chicago Board Options Exchange's fear gauge, the VIX, also hit a record close on March 17th, surpassing its 2008 High. As a result, even gold, silver, oil, bitcoin and other global safe-haven assets have been short-term panic, stampede-type sell-off, Japan, Europe and other major global stock indexes have fallen. More seriously, in response to the liquidity crisis, the Federal Reserve cut interest rates on the 15th local time, cut the target range of the federal funds rate to a very low level of 0-0.25% , and launched a $700 billion quantitative easing program, it was a one-off "all in" that fired all the bullets of short-term monetary policy, but the markets did not seem to buy it, and US stocks began to melt again, leaving no doubt that the developed world was experiencing a liquidity crisis.

The immediate cause is the global spread of the disease, and the most effective way to stop the spread of the virus before a vaccine can be made would undoubtedly be to dramatically reduce human to human contact, while the economies of Europe and the United States rely heavily on consumption, a sharp reduction in people-to-people contact will no doubt suppress aggregate demand in the short term. The industries that will be affected more severely will include tourism, catering, entertainment, transportation, etc. . The reduction in aggregate demand will directly lead to a sharp decline in the profitability of listed companies, overall economic growth will fall with it.

Apple, for example, recently announced that it would close all its stores outside of Greater China, and starbucks, for example, same-store sales in China in February alone fell 78 per cent from a year earlier, leading to an expected drop in global sales over the next few months.

The logic of the sharp decline in the short-term capital market is becoming clear: the decrease in aggregate demand causes the rapid decline in the profitability of listed companies, the decline in the stock prices of listed companies results in the decrease of market risk preference, and the increase in the demand for money, the sell-off began with the loss of margin for highly leveraged groups, followed by a stampede and subsequent falls in other asset prices.

Therefore, the developed countries' major central banks "cut interest rates + Qe" policy to supplement market liquidity in the short term is indeed a certain benefit. But monetary policy is not a panacea, and the root cause of the short-term liquidity crisis is the excessive bubble in capital markets over the past decade and problems in the structure of the economy itself.

U.S. stocks have been on a 10 year bull run since 2009, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average up more than three times from its low in early 2009 to its high earlier this year, and the Nasdaq up more than six times. The initial rise in the US stock market was also mainly due to the resumption of profits of listed companies brought about by the economic recovery after the financial crisis, in the middle and later period, it was mainly because of the loose monetary environment and the low interest rate environment that listed companies used the capital market to raise funds to buy back stocks, and some companies in the loss and earnings are not strong companies also increased the proportion of dividends resulting from the wealth effect. It can also be said that market investors at this stage to earn more money than the actual profits of the enterprise loose money. In this case, any black swan is undoubtedly a fatal blow to the stock market, a few years ago some well-known investors have made every year the peak of the U. S. stock market forecasts is also seen in the existence of this problem.

In the economic structure, many factors supporting the economic development of developed countries have been quietly changing in recent years, the problem of population ageing in demography is getting worse, and technological progress has slowed in recent years, preventing productivity from rising dramatically, the developed world has had to rely too heavily on monetary policy in order to maintain its potential growth, in other words, by holding down interest rates or even by taking negative interest rates and raising debt levels, while too loose money has pushed up asset prices, has increased the gap between the rich and the poor. The combined wealth of the top 1 per cent of households is almost equal to the wealth of the entire middle and upper-middle class. The gap between the rich and the poor is too wide to expand the total demand is very disadvantageous, the bottom residents have the consumption will but not the consumption ability. This was evident in the series of tax measures that Sounders proposed in the recent Democratic primary, and which many ordinary Americans embraced.

From the above logic, the outbreak is only a trigger rather than the root cause of the outbreak, so on the basis of increasing efforts to effectively control the epidemic, the way to rescue can not be limited to monetary policy. Monetary policy is a cure-all for short-term market liquidity crises, not a cure-all, much less a cure-all that has been in use for years. According to the Fisher equation: money supply x Velocity of money price (p) x production (Q) . In a context where aggregate demand can not expand because of the epidemic, an acceleration in the money supply could reduce Velocity of money, rather than raise prices or increase output, given the current record high leverage of non financial companies in the United States, businesses and households will not be very willing to increase lending, which could leave the extra money sitting in banks and not stimulating the economy or capital markets. Therefore, to achieve the effect of short-term economic boost must also be used in conjunction with fiscal policy, rather than allowing money to accumulate in financial markets, it is better to direct the distribution of money to residents. "helicopter money" , as Bernanke put it, is now a good option, with tax rebates or other forms of direct subsidy to households or consumers after the central bank imposes zero or near zero interest rates. Recently, the US media reported that the US may launch a large-scale stimulus policy, which includes issuing a $1,000 check to every US citizen. In addition, if the United States can open related protectionist policies to stimulate its domestic consumption will also play a good role.

Of course, short-term monetary and fiscal stimulus can only be temporary measures, such as short-term policy for the long-term will make future problems more complex, more difficult to solve, the impact on the global economy as a whole more far-reaching financial. In the long run, changing the structure of income distribution, supplementing the purchasing power at the bottom and changing the debt-driven growth pattern are the fundamental solutions to the problem.

The writer is a financial commentator

I'm sorry. I'm sorry. I'm sorry. I'm sorry
